definition[0]: a secret that someone tells people, or the act of telling this secret
example[0]: the disclosure of private medical information
definition[1]: the duty of someone in a professional position to inform customers, shareholders etc about facts that will influence their decisions
example[1]: The code of conduct is based on the need for disclosure, which ensures that all those with a legitimate interest in a company have the information which they need.
definition[2]: when a person or organization gives information that would normally be kept secret, for example when a bank gives information about a customer’s accounts to the police
example[2]: In America ‘shield’ laws allow journalists to protect their sources, with certain exceptions, for example if public interest is better served by disclosure.
definition[3]: the duty of someone who is insured to tell the insurance company every important fact that relates to the insurance
definition[4]: a fact which is made known after being kept secret
example[3]: There was criticism of his salary and tax arrangements following disclosures in the newspapers.
